captions.text:
Hey guys, I'm Tom Phillips and welcome to
Five Things. In case you haven't heard, WWE

Network has added every single episode of
Clash of the Champions. Clash of the Champions

was WCW's version of Saturday Night Main Event
and featured the best WCW had to offer. Today

we're looking at 5 matches you must check
out!

Number 1 is from the first ever Clash of the
Champions, it's Sting versus Ric Flair. Their

rivalry spanned almost an entire decade and
was the final match in WCW history. This specific

meeting lasted nearly 45 minutes and was considered
by many as Match of the Year.

Ric Flair also comes in at number 2. His 2
out of 3 falls match with Ricky Steamboat

is one of their best matches. Fun fact, this
show took place at the home of WrestleMania

30, The Superdome.
Ricky "The Dragon" Steamboat gets a second

match on this list at number 3. Steamboat
and "Stone Cold" Steve Austin had classic

matches and 2 of their best took place at
Clash of the Champions. They first met in

1992 but we're looking at their 1994 match
instead. As it turned out, this would be The

Dragon's final match for nearly 15 years.
We're going to stick to "Stone Cold" Steve

Austin for number 4. Austin and Brian Pillman
were known as the Hollywood Blondes and in

1993 they challenged Arn Anderson and the
returning Ric Flair.  That is the thrid time for Ric Flair on this list.

This awesome match is known for being the first time in 2 years
Ric Flair competed in a WCW ring.

Number 5 is Rey Mysterio facing Dean Malenko
in 1996. Mysterio and Malenko stole the show

and this match is a great example of why the
Cruiserweights were a must-see division in

WCW.
Well there are five Clash of the Champions

matches you must check out. WCW aired 35 Clash
of the Champions meaning there are hundreds

of new matches to binge watch on the WWE Network.
I'm Tom Phillips, thanks for joining me today
on Five Things.

title: 5 Awesome Clash of the Champions Matches - 5 Things

comments.author: Moey Hasn

comments.text:
Rey was certainly a big factor in the smaller guys being taken more 
seriously, he could outshine anybody on the card with his talent. Problem 
is when he became champion they booked him so poorly, he hardly won a match 
cleanly as world heavyweight champion, which reflects the prejudice against 
smaller competitors throughout the years. The title didn't make Mysterio, 
his incredible talent did... and he'd been proving that years before he won 
that title...But yeah I agree Rey Mysterio is one of the greatest of all 
time and he paved the way for guys like Bryan, and hopefully for WWE to put 
agility and talent over sheer muscle mass and height.
comments.author: Orphean Caprica

comments.text:
For one, Rey Mysterio is my favourite wrestler and that title is the thing 
that made him... We'll him and Rey is a former Heavyweight and WWE champ so 
I guess small guys do get the WWE championship sometimes and the 
Cruiserweight Sometimes...
comments.author: Moey Hasn

comments.text:
Agreed:) For me ever since the days of Dynamite Kid and Ricky Steamboat the 
smaller guys have always been the most talented competitor's on the roster. 
Of course they were usually regulated to the mid-card in favour of the 
giants. DB being champ really feels like a breakthrough, like yourself I 
hope WWE sticks with that in the future and gives the smaller guys the 
opportunity they deserve:)
comments.author: Orphean Caprica

comments.text:
There has been a stigma about only big guys making it. Daniel Bryan is a 
shining example of that stigma being broken. Guys that lack muscle tone, 
height, guys like Sami Zayn and Adrian Neville in NXT, being too small for 
example. Thats why its so pleasing to see Bryan on the top!
comments.author: Lionheart TV

comments.text:
Small guys not making it? Have you seen the size of the current WWE World

guys not making it, it's surely that. I miss the cruiserweights too, but 
surely it just sidelines guys to that division and thus the mid-card 
instead of mixing it up in the main events.

comments.text:
Here's the drawback to those Clashes and why WCW phased them out:  Mike 
Graham said that producing them cost about the same as producing PPVs.  
Also, WCW made shortchanging Austin a habit.  It curtailed the Hollywood 
Blonds' momentum in '93 for political reasons and decided not to give him 
world title shots he was supposed to get in '94 because of Hulk Hogan's 
arrival to the promotion.  At least Austin had some great matches while he 
still had hair!﻿
